title: In Situ TEM Study and Control of Octahedral Units’ Migration in Rutile TiO2
content: The advancement of ultra-small electronic and spintronic devices relies on high-quality semiconducting or magnetic thin films. Precise control of each atomic layer’s growth is essential to improve the quality of few-nm-thick films during material synthesis. This requires a deep understanding of the nanometer-scale material migration under different conditions. However, directly observing the motion of individual atomic units along the surface of crystalline materials in response to applied fields presents a significant challenge. Here, we used in-situ electrical biasing transmission electron microscopy (TEM) to study the atomic units’ movements in rutile TiO2 thin film with nano-meter-width cracks under applied electric fields. Distinct materials migration processes were observed, different from previously observed electron-beam-radiolysis driven movements [1]. These new observations obtained by operando TEM are promising for improving thin film synthesis and providing insights into atomic migration mechanisms in electronic devices.
